column4: is it possible to grep or otherwise take an ip that is in a text file and put it in a new txt file?
i thought it would be something like that
is that perl?
no
so that info is in the man?
yup
i apologize
It can be done many ways, thats just the first one I thought off, sed and awk can do it too
Why in the world are you apologizing
because i didnt read the man and i know that is annoying
Thats pretty advanced grep so not anoying. Took me many years of doing it wrong to get there
i must be doing something wrong because the txt it makes is empty

i got it to work, but the man is confusing, would it be a bother if i asked you if it is possible to limit the '[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}' to find only one instance of each????? '{[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}2\}' didn't work

cat /var/log/auth.log | grep "password for root" > ~/roothack.txt && cat roothack.txt | grep -o '[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}\.[0-9]\{1,3\}' | sort -u > banlist.txt && for line in $(cat banlist.txt); do iptables -I INPUT -s "$line" -j DROP; done
Awesome, glad you got it workig
do you like it?
yeah
you could shorten it a little by not using cat
using instead?
